speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Yes, but -- but it is true you have a strong textual - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I was a little bit surprised 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 at your opening because it seems to me you have a strong textual argument you're now defending.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What does a holistic reading mean? Can you stay within the - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, let -- let me ask - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, the problem for the court below was that the person covered can ask for it in a lump sum and pay a penalty.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Right, and that's not - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: And -- and that isn't then on the basis of age. Am I right? Is that -- that was the problem the court had below.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, when you say full enjoyment, you -- you think when -- when I'm taxed on something, I -- I don't have full enjoyment of it? Once you reach a certain age, you can withdraw it without -- without paying the 10 percent tax.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, I'm sure it does, but - - but it's -- it's hard to accept the notion that simply because after a certain age I get a tax benefit, I'm receiving the money on account of my age. That doesn't make any sense to me.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Ms. Karlan, the -- as long as this money was in the plan, it was shielded from bankruptcy, and there are -- there was not unlimited access even with the penalty when it was in the plan. speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Another employer's plan. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: All right. Well, then - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- then you might persuade me.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Yes. That was what I was going -- aren't most of the pension profit-sharing, stock bonus plans, and annuities similar to the IRA's in terms of allowing withdrawal on the payment of a penalty?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Oh, it's the Eighth Circuit. Excuse me. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It -- it might be wrong anyway. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What is the percentage amount of the payments that are taken out of all IRA plans before people are 59 and a half?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And the -- the payment here - - it says -- the statute uses the word payment. So suppose you simply have an IRA plan but you don't take money out of it. Then is it exempt from bankruptcy?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So -- so -- but I'm trying - - what I'm trying to figure out is if a person were to take -- just reading it in English, it sounds as if a person were to take the plan out before he's 59 and a half and 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 pay the penalty, that that amount that he took out would not be a -- a payment because of age, but one that he took out after he's 59 and a half and didn't pay the penalty would be.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Ms. Karlan, let me ask something about that very point because the statute says that to the extent reasonably necessary for the support of the debtor it's allowable.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Can we take this concrete case? Hers was something over $12,000; his, something over $42,000.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What was the claim here as to -- was part or all of that -- it would be some $54,000.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What -- what do the courts do if they say, well, my client might be ill or something like that? It seems to me - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: No, no. They -- they say my client is able-bodied now, but we -- we need something because -- I don't know -- there's a history of family illness or something.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER

So it's very tempting to say that that corpus there, of course, is a body of money that you're going to have a right to receive because of age because the practical effect of the 10 percent is -- is -- stops the -- the younger person getting the money. So does the case then turn on that? I mean, suppose -- suppose it were a 3 percent penalty and 40 percent of the people took out the money before they were 60 or a 1 percent penalty and 80 percent did it. Then should I reach the other result? I'm just trying to think of how does this analysis work. What's the right analysis?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What percent?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, they're taking out loans against it. They're -- they're not withdrawing the money.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So you say that payment doesn't -- on account of doesn't modify payment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Holistic for me. What -- what does it -- what does it modify? I mean, if you had to diagram it, on account of goes to what noun?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No. I thought I was being holistic yesterday, to tell you the truth. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But - - 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- but what does on account of modify?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Where -- where is that noun?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The right to receive a payment under a stock bonus, pension - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- profit sharing, annuity, or similar plan or -- or contract. It's a plan on account of illness, an annuity?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Why -- why isn't it a right on account of?

speakers.text: So -- so then you're - - you're - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But as purely English -- as purely English, I read it as saying it's a right. What is that right? The right is a right to receive a payment on account of age. That's the -- a plan. That's the right. Now, your argument, I take it, was -- is that yes, it's true you also have a right under certain conditions to take it without respect to age. So what we have here is a plan that gives you both kind of rights.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It's a kind that gives you a right to take it with a penalty and a right to take it because of age without a penalty. And thus, the question is, is that kind of plan which gives you both kind of rights covered? And the language doesn't answer it. So - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But under Justice Breyer's hypothetical, that's just like a savings account.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER

Isn't that your -- your strong point?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's your strong point.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Right. Right -- it's not a right if you have to pay a penalty for it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's a good argument. I like that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Why didn't Congress just put in IRA's along with the other things?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Yes, but that's sort of an oblique way to get it there. I mean, why didn't they put it together with the other string of plans?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: What --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What your -- what your opponents say is that the -- the thing at the end doesn't 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 prove anything because they're willing to acknowledge that some IRA's can be so structured that you cannot withdraw until -- until you reach a certain age. speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Do -- do we know that? I mean, couldn't someone -- I -- I don't think this is a very plausible basis for construing the statute, but just as a technical matter, couldn't someone go to the bank or brokerage firm and say I want to set up an IRA, but I want the IRA to be, in -- in effect, like an irrevocable trust in which withdrawals can only be made on certain, specific conditions? speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And some don't. And the -- 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 and the State systems vary.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: As opposed to how many who do?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, that's what -- with the purpose that we're talking about now --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But here there was no choice of picking up on the State?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But you -- that was your 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 claim, and I - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: How did you come to that conclusion, that the entire amount?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well. Oh, yes.

speakers.text: May I go back and just nail down one lose end in -- in an answer that you -- you gave to my question, can you set up a kind of irrevocable? speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA

speakers.text: Ms. McKiever.

speakers.text: What -- what - -

That's what I would like to hear because to me, I'm not so moved by holistic as I am by purposes, which is part of holistic. So -- so the -- the point that I would like to know is why, since ordinary people think of IRA's as pensions -- I do. I think of it that way. I don't know much about it. It's designed to help in the future, help when you're old and sick. But there is this extra thing in it which you point to. So why, in terms of purposes is this different from the others?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I know that, but -- but -- and you do it with a penalty. We agree about the facts. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.text: But I want to know why that difference makes a difference in a world where only 1 or less 2 percent of the people do access it before they're 60, 59 and a half.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, no. I -- you've missed my point and I'm sorry. I put you on the wrong track with my following up. I shouldn't have.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: My question is we all agree that there can be plans where you can get the money not having to do with age, and they fall within the language of the act, and indeed, you say some are covered. But this one you say is worse than the others in terms of the purposes of the act, and that's what I want to hear why.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I - - 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I ask this question? Supposing instead of a 10 percent penalty, there was an absolute prohibition, would you agree -- on getting the money before you're 59 and a half, would then that qualify?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Now, what if there were a 50 percent penalty?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And what is it that makes it a prohibition? Is it -- is it because the purpose is to deter withdrawals, or it is that it becomes economically unacceptable? What -- what is the reason for drawing the line somewhere above 10 percent?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But what is the purpose of imposing any penalty at all?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But 50 percent would not be a prohibition and neither would 90 percent.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: So it's a matter of degree rather than a difference in kind.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: It seems to me the easiest black letter rule is no tax or some tax. I mean, if it was totally free like an ordinary bank account, then you'd be dead right. speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I assume - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- that -- that your answer to 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 Justice Breyer as to why that makes a difference with regard to the purpose of the statute is that the purpose of the statute is to make sure that people have money for their retirement, and that if you can withdraw it for any reason whatever, there is no security that that money will be there for their retirement; whereas if you limit the reasons to sickness and -- and a certain other number of emergency reasons, the chances the money will be there for the retirement are much higher.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Isn't that the answer?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But if that's the answer, excellent. So now we have -- (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- let's say - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Let's try -- let's try a million percent tax and nobody in history has ever withdrawn the money. Now, would -- that you would say would fall within this.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Fine, yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay. Now, if that would fall within this, going back to Justice Stevens, because that 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 operates as a bar to prevent the bad world that Justice Scalia mentioned, why doesn't a tax that operates as a bar that's good enough to stop 98.5 percent of the people from withdrawing their money and having nothing left for old age -- why isn't that just as good as the million percent tax in a world that is imperfect?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But attachment of the - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: All right, but it's acquired. Say -- say retirement, not old age. I mean, you know, 60 -- it's not that bad - - (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: JUSTICE SOUTER: If -- if that is going to be your criterion, the -- the total freedom for any purpose, then why, if we accept your argument, why -- why don't we face sort of a daunting run or the courts face sort of daunting future? Because the -- the question then is going to be, well, what purposes are sufficiently close to old age to -- to allow for a continued exemption and how 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 free may the purposes be before a plan falls into the IRA category. You told us a few moments ago -- and I'm sure you -- you were right -- that the kind of the paradigm example plans vary enormously depending on the terms in which employers set them up. So if -- if we say that the -- the dividing line is going to be between plans under which withdrawal can be for any purpose versus plans in which withdrawal is going to be somehow limited, then we're going to have to litigate an awful lot of plans. Aren't we?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, but typically these plans like 401(k) plans permit hardship withdrawals, and other plans that are mentioned in the act allow withdrawals for medical reasons or to buy housing or something like that. I mean, you -- we would just have endless cases trying to figure out what qualifies and what doesn't. It seems like such a hard line for you to try to draw here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: And every plan that I know of allows withdrawal if you terminate employment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: In fact, that's what happened to these people. So I just don't see how your argument is going to --

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Isn't it simpler to just recognize that these plans are covered despite the right to withdraw and then rely on the provision in the statute that only permits the deduction to the extent reasonably necessary for the support? I mean, that -- that seems to me a fall-back position that's provided for in the statute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: No. Well, obviously, it's - - it's governed by the statutory provision that it has to be a stock bonus, pension, profit-sharing, annuity, or similar plan or contract on account of, and so on.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: And it includes IRA's apparently because of the last provision in the statute referring back to individual retirement acts under section 408 of the Internal Revenue Code.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Ms. -- Ms. Karlan says she 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 doesn't know of any -- of any IRA that did place a -- a restriction which would bring it within that exemption even though the ordinary IRA wouldn't be within the exemption. Do you know of any IRA, a single IRA that - - that has a provision in it restricting withdrawal?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: They can, but do -- do you know that there's -- there's one out there? I don't know - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You didn't just draw one up for this case, did you? (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Was that -- was that an IRA that she had? It was an IRA?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Let me -- let me ask you. Maybe this is irrelevant, but were -- were these restrictive IRA's that you're aware of set up under those terms in contemplation of bankruptcy? If the answer is no, why would anyone so restrict his -- his IRA?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But why -- why would anyone do that? They're -- they're qualified without these restrictions. Why would anyone want to cut off his -- his rights to -- to withdraw?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: In other words, like setting up a personal spendthrift trust?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: I -- I want to make it tough so that I -- I will not be tempted to withdraw. Is that the 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 motivation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Should we put any weight on the title, on the name? I mean, I -- I can't but thinking it's an individual retirement account. Was Congress trying to fool people? (Laughter.)

speakers.text: Was the Federal Trade Commission? Should they investigate? What -- I mean, the -- the -- I think of it as an account that's basically aimed, at least Congress thought it was aimed, at retirement, which has usually to do with age.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I'm reading the statute and if I were voting on it and put in the 408 reference and think of the word individual retirement account, is there any - - I would have thought, knowing not that much about it, that 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 of course, they'd be included. speakers.text: So it's just -- just like an IRA.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA

speakers.text: Yes. At least as to the 10 percent that would be penalty, there's no right to get that money unless you have a certain age.

speakers.text: You don't dispute that - - that it's a very small percentage of people who have IRA's, in fact, exercise the right to withdraw, given the penalty.

speakers.text: The words, on account of, in this -- this statute are sort of unusual, no matter how you construe them, because really the payment is on account of the years of service or it's on account of a lot of things. You may become eligible at a certain time. It would be better if it said a payment for which you became eligible for one of these reasons because the payment isn't really on account of all of these things. You may get the same amount whether you're disabled or not depending on what the terms of the plan are.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Does your argument draw a ring around IRA's? It was suggested that if your argument prevails, then these other plans would be affected as well.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Thank you, Ms. McKiever. Ms. Karlan, you have about 7 minutes. You're not required to use it all.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You don't really have a right to receive it on account of age. You have a right to receive it without a penalty on account of age.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It isn't the right to receive the money that depends on your age. It's the right to receive the money without paying a tax.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It is a right that's important, 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 but it's not what the statute says. The statute says - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- the right to receive a payment on account of, among other things, age.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No, but it lists the other reasons: on account of illness, disability, death, age, or length of service. And -- and, you know, when you have a list like that, you would think that the right to receive the money for some other reason doesn't -- doesn't qualify. I mean, I would think that that's - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Or -- or at least -- at least some other reason that isn't closely related to those.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Is it true that none of them give unfettered access? They're all qualified in some fashion. Do you agree with that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, yes. You -- you don't have to make up a hardship. You just say I want the money. Okay, you want the money? Here's the money.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't even have to lie about the hardship. I mean -- (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: In any of these other plans, can you get the money so long as you're willing to pay a penalty?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Without any qualification for disability, illness. No. I just want the money. Give me the money and I'll pay you 10 percent. Is there any plan that works like that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Has any judge ever taken the view that -- adopting Justice Scalia's approach, that while you can't put the whole IRA -- exempt the whole IRA, but you can exempt 10 percent of it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: At least you ought to get that much, it seems to me, under his -- his analysis.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Thank you. The case is submitted.
